Bad Faith: The violation of Florida Statutes governing the timely and proper adjustment practices of insurance claims. Typically, bad faith can include unwarranted delay or denial of insurance benefits, unfair or deceptive practices, and misrepresentations of fact. Depending on the magnitude of the bad faith, Florida Statutes allow for the recovery of extra-contractual damages (damages beyond the terms of the insurance policy) and/or punitive damages. At Cassel & Cassel, we strive to make the claim process as pain-free and easy to understand as possible. Below is a glossary of terms commonly used throughout property insurance policies and claim correspondences. Please note that this is not meant to be an exhaustive list, and these terms are defined generally as individual policies may contain alternative definitions. If you have any questions regarding the definitions below or their application to your claim/policy, do not hesitate to contact one of our attorneys for a free consultation. https://lnkd.in/d6zSc3U

On August 1, 2024, new Minnesota legislation that addresses insurance coverage on real estate subject to a Transfer on Death Deed (TODD) will take effect. The new law extends temporary insurance coverage under the property owner’s policy to TODD beneficiaries under certain circumstances. Learn what you need to know on our blog: https://bit.ly/46oqlyp #TransferOnDeathDeed #MNLaw #RealEstateInsurance #HenningsonAndSnoxell

The Hon’ble Supreme Court recently dismissed the appeals filed by insurance companies against a Judgment of Hon’ble NCDRC vide which the NCDRC had directed the Insurance companies to pay the sum as per the Fire Perils insurance policies to the insured Cold Storage from the date of repudiation along with interest: The Hon’ble NCDRC, in its judgment, dealt with important and recurring issues like: 1. Whether Insurance Claim is payable when there is a case of double insurance; 2. Whether Insurance Claim is payable when the stock insured does not belong to the Insured; 3. Whether the insurance company can deny payment of claim on the basis of “Goods held in Trust” are not covered under the policy; The Cold Storage/Complainant before the NCDRC as well as before the SC was represented by Senior Advocate Arvind Nayar along-with other advocates. Attaching the Judgment passed by the Hon’ble Supreme Court and the Hon'ble NCDRC for the benefit of readers.

Arrowood Indemnity, the runoff entity for Royal Indemnity and Royal Globe, was recently declared insolvent by the Delaware commissioner of insurance. This action was taken through the filing of a complaint for entry of a liquidation and injunction order with a bar date. Partner Les Brown discusses how thousands of policyholders seeking insurance recovery may be affected in this update. https://bit.ly/3sy07dl #Insurance #InsuranceLaw #InsurancePolicy

The insurance claim process may take longer in some claims as opposed to others. Our attorneys can help you through the adjustment process and make an otherwise stressful situation more tolerable. We can work with the carrier to try to resolve your claim as quickly as possible. Sometimes, however, an insurance company may act outside the scope of the policy or applicable law. In these situations, our courtroom experience allows us to hold insurance companies accountable for unreasonable tactics and bad faith insurance practices. If you have experienced an underpayment of benefits or an outright claim denial, or if you have experienced bad faith insurance practices, contact the attorneys at Cassel & Cassel for a free evaluation.
